00108 typedef struct {
00109         molindex s,t; // source & target atoms for bond
00110         double o; // order 
00111         bond_type *typ; // pointer to type of bond
00112         int i; // index -- for example as alternative to *typ
00113         char *D; // free-form description
00114 } molbond; // set of consecutive bonds

00116 typedef struct {
00117         int n;  // number of these
00118         molbond *b; // n of them
00119         char *D; // free-form description
00120 } molbondset; // set of consecutive bonds

00122 typedef struct {
00123         molindex a,b,c; // three atoms in the angle
00124         double ang; // the angle
00125         angle_type *typ; // pointer to type of angle
00126         char *D;// free-form descriptor
00127         int i; // index -- for example as alternative to *typ
00128 } angle_index; // index to atoms in an angle
00129 typedef struct {
00130         molindex a,b,c,d; // four atoms defining the torsion
00131         double ang; // the angle
00132         torsion_type *typ; // pointer to type of torsion
00133         char *D;// free-form descriptor
00134         int i; // index -- for example as alternative to *typ
00135 } torsion_index; // index to atoms in an angle

00339 /* The following is a set of functions intended primarily to facilitate 
00340 debugging.  But, they could easily be used for verbose data output within
00341 the program.  They all follow the same basic format:
00342 
00343 print_X(X *x, int level)
00344 
00345 where   X = one of the structures defined above (e.g., molecule, residue, 
00346                 bondset, atom, bond, atype, plane, vectormag_3D, coord_3D).
00347         *x = pointer to your structure
00348         level = the depth to print.  This is only available on structures 
00349                 likely to contain arrays of other structures.  level=0 only
00350                 prints the top-level information.  level=1 prints one level 
00351                 down of other structures, lists, etc. level=2 prints two 
00352                 levels down, etc.   The value of level can be larger than 
00353                 the depth available -- the function will stop when it runs
00354                 out of structures to print.  
00355 */
00356 int NUMAT; 
00357 void print_molecule(molecule*,int),print_residue(residue*,int);
00358 void print_bondset(bondset*,int),print_atom(atom*,int),print_bond(bond*);
00359 void print_atype(atype*,int),print_plane(plane*);
00360 void print_vectormag_3D(vectormag_3D*),print_coord_3D(coord_3D*);

00364 void dprint_atype(atype*,int),dprint_plane(plane*);
00365 void dprint_vectormag_3D(vectormag_3D*),dprint_coord_3D(coord_3D*);

00368 void dXprint_bondset(bondset*,int),dXprint_atom(atom*,int),dXprint_bond(bond*);
00369 void dXprint_atype(atype*,int),dXprint_plane(plane*);
00370 void dXprint_vectormag_3D(vectormag_3D*),dXprint_coord_3D(coord_3D*);

00372 /* the following are geometric operations for the structures defined above 
00373         where int is xl ("x" (coordinate) location):
00374                 xl refers to position in the atom structure
00375                         xl=-1 means use the atom.x structure
00376                         xl=0,1,2,etc means use the atom.xa[xl] or
00377                                 the atom.v[xl] structure
00378         where int,int is "xl,vl" it refers to coord and vector location
00379                 (in that order).
00380         where int is n
00381                 n indicates the number of blocks in the preceding pointer
00382 
00383    All of the following that involve vectors will set the magnitude of 
00384         the resulting vector without relying on the entry in the input 
00385         vector.  So, for example, there is no need to get_magnitude 
00386         before normalizing or multiplying by a scalar.
00387 */
00388 /* this moves all the coords in molecule so that the center of mass
00389 for the molecule is at the origin (right now, though, it only works
00390 if the molecule has only one residue...*/
00391 void translate_to_COM(molecule *,atype *,int); // int is xl
00392         // this assumes the initial coords are in atom.x
00393 //void translate_zero_to_COM(molecule *,atype *,int,int); 
00394         // int#1 is xs, the location of the source coords
00395         // int#2 is xt, the location of the translated coords
00396 void translate_zero_to_coord_M(molecule *,int,int,coord_3D); 
00397         // int#1 is xs, the location of the source coords
00398         // int#2 is xt, the location of the translated coords
00399 void assign_residue_COM(residue *r,atype *ATYPE);
00400 void assign_molecule_COM(molecule *m,atype *ATYPE);
00401 void assign_assembly_COM(assembly *a,atype *ATYPE);
00402 void assign_ensemble_COM(ensemble *e,atype *ATYPE);
00403 coord_3D get_residue_COM(residue *r,atype *ATYPE,int xs);
00404 coord_3D get_molecule_COM(molecule *m,atype *ATYPE,int xs);
00405 coord_3D get_assembly_COM(assembly *a,atype *ATYPE,int xs);
00406 coord_3D get_ensemble_COM(ensemble *e,atype *ATYPE,int xs);

00408 /* the following functions rotate the coordinate list such that the
00409 vector given by vectormag_3D points along the Z (Y, X, other) axis.
00410 The orientation of the orthogonal axes is arbitrary. */
00411 void rotate_vector_to_Z_M(molecule*,int,int,int,int,vectormag_3D); 
00412         // The four integers are:
00413         // int#1 location of source coordinates (-1=x, 0,1,2,etc=xa[xs]
00414         // int#2 location of rotated coordinates (-1=x, 0,1,2,etc=xa[xs]
00415         // int#3 location of source vectors (-1=do not calc, 0,1,2,etc=v[xs]
00416         // int#4 location of rotated vectors (-1=do not calc, 0,1,2,etc=v[xs]
00417 void rotate_vector_to_Z_list(coord_3D*,int,vectormag_3D); // int is n
